did.head: Summary Information
did.abstract: The Johnson, J. mss. consists of materials devised by Jane (Russell) Johnson primarily for the instruction of her son, George William Johnson. The materials consist of 438 items and are arranged in 24 groups. Included are alphabet cards, religious and secular lesson cards, all hand-made. Some contain colored illustrations and are decorated with multi-colored Dutch paper.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Jane (Russell) Johnson, 1706-1759, of Witham-on-the-Hill, Lincolnshire, England, primarily for the instruction of her son, George William Johnson, 1740?-1814, High Sheriff of Lincolnshire in 1784, and presumably for the two other sons and daughter as well. Jane Johnson was the wife of the Rev. Woolsey Johnson, 1696?-1756, who built Witham Hall in 1752, and the daughter of Richard Russell who acquired Packwood Manor in 1715 (subsequently heired by Jane to her sister Lucy) which was eventually sold to Sir Horace Mann.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The materials are arranged in 24 groups.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Johnson, J. mss. consists of materials devised by Jane (Russell) Johnson primarily for the instruction of her son, George William Johnson. The materials consist of 438 items and are arranged in 24 groups. Included are alphabet cards, religious and secular lesson cards, all hand-made. Some contain colored illustrations and are decorated with multi-colored Dutch paper.

The materials, arranged in 24 groups, consist of 438 pieces. Present are six sets of alphabet cards, many with vowel sounds, syllables, words and short lines or verses (which could serve as modern flash cards); three sets of word cards, also with vowel sounds, syllables and lines; two booklets; three sets of lesson cards in verse and anecdotal form on religious and secular topics; five card sets, largely secular and contemporary in nature with some traditional story-verses; and three card sets of religious and moral instruction, along with a set of word chips.

The largest group of materials is that of set no. 7 which includes the 78 word chips denoting chiefly food products such as Ale, Almonds, Bacon, ... , Veal, Water, Wild-fowl, housed in a small paper box decorated with playing card symbols cut from a Dutch-made paper.

References to contemporary personages and secular topics include George Berkeley, bishop of Cloyne, who advocated the curative powers of tarwater (no. 14 - Doctor Berkeley and Enoch Martyr cards); John Thomas, Bishop of London (no. 14 - Master Isaac Seabright); George Wright, member of Parliament (no. 14 - Two tame swans); the French dances, ridotto (no. 19 - Lord Mountjoy) and rigadoon (no. 19 - Miss Carpenter); anti-French bias (no. 17 - Hark the drums and no. 21 - Such short gowns); an acrobat (no. 21 - This Girl to get money); a woman's independence (no. 21 - Pray Madam come this way); toothache (no. 18 - A Boy and a Girl).

The stories, briefly noted, include those of the faithful dog betrayed (no. 14 - A farmer came home); A Fable (no. 15 - The Old man and Death: he calls upon Death but when he appears, asks for help with his load); The Eagle and the Child (no. 15 - As a hungry eagle: it seizes the child from the cradle); and a nonsense rhyme (no. 18 - If all the world was [sic] paper).
Sets 22 and 23 contain many identical religious and moral statements, including five of the Ten Commandments.

Factors for dating the material are derived from a figure on a card which bears a printed identity (set 1, item 36: Sir John Bernard, alderman and Lord Mayor of London, 1738); one of the booklets (no. 11 - George William Johnson, his Book, Printed and Bound by his Mamma [Jane Johnson] 1745); and a card (no. 14 - Simon Lord Lovat) which notes that Lord Lovat was beheaded on April 9, 1747.

The materials are sturdily constructed of two or more pieces of paper pasted together, some of which bear partial watermarks, with the wording hand-printed on grooved lines in black and red ink. Bordered or decorated in brown, orange, and green multi-colored paper of Dutch origin, the cards frequently are illustrated by figures (plain or hand-colored) of people, birds, animals, and objects cut from printed sources. One of the illustrations retains its printed source (set 21, item 15: Sold by John Bowles at the Black Horse in Cornhill). Many of the cards have small string or cord hangers.

controlaccess.head: Indexing Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in IUCAT, the IU Libraries' online catalog. Materials about related topics, persons or places can be found by searching the catalog using these terms.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: Prior arrangements are not necessary before coming to the Library, however, patrons from out of town are encouraged to communicate with the Library in advance of their visits to ascertain availability of materials.
Photocopying permitted only with the permission of the Curator of Manuscripts, Lilly Library

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [item], Johnson, J. mss., Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana

scopecontent.p: Set of 12 unnumbered cards, 2 letters of the alphabet and 2 lines to a card, omitting the letters "j" and "u." Plain uncolored pictures in the center of card. Verso blank. 12 items.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: a/ Was an Al-der-man, in a fine Gown,/ b/ Was a Bar-ber, that Shaved his Crown.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: c/ Was a Cob-ler, and liv'd in a Stall./ d/ Was a Draw-er, Pray Sir do you Call?

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: e/ Was an em-press, en-ro-bed in black./ f/ Was a Fox, with a Goose at his back.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: g/ Was a good man, that bought and sold hogs./ h/ Was a Hunter, quite fond of his Dogs.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: i/ Was an ink-horn, as black as a Crow./ k/ Was a keep-er, and shot at a Doe.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: l/ Was a la-dy, whose beau-ty was frail,/ m/ Was a Monk-key, with-out a-ny Tail.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: n/ Was a naugh-ty Boy....in his dish,/ o/ Was an Ot-ter, that eat up the fish.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: p/ Was a Py-rate and Rob'd on the Seas./ q/ Was a qua-ker, as stiff as you please.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: r/ Was a Rab-bet, as brisk as a Bee./ s/ Was a Squir-rel, and Tripp'd on a tree.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: t/ Was a Tra-der, and ga-ther'd up pelf./ u/ Was as ug-ly as AEsop him-self.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: w/ Was a Wa-ter-man, and ply'd in the Creeks/ x/ Was that Xerx-es that fought with the Greeks

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: y/ Was a Yeo-man could Blust-er and strut/ z/ Was a Zea-lot, and liv'd in a Hutt.

note.p: Ash cash dash lash/ bat cat rat sprat/ daw law paw caw/ ax tax wax flax/ day gay hay may/ blaze gaze glaze maze

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: beak beak speak/ eel heel feel kneel/ beam cream dream/ eat meat neat seat/ feet meet street great/ beck deck neck peck

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Bed fed red wed/ bee fee see lee thee/ deed feed seed bleed/ creep deep keep/ bell fell sell well/ elf pelf self shelf

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Den hen men pen/ best drest nest rest/ bet fret let net wet/ bib crib gib nib rib/ dice ice mice rice/ lick kick stick brick

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Bid did kid lid rid/ fig pig sprig twig/ bill fill hill mill rill/ brim grim him skim/ pin tin chin skin/ bind find kind wind

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Hit pit sit wit spit/ bite mite write quite/ five hive dive drive/ bob job mob rob fob/ nod rod jod clod God/ bog dog hog frog

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Cold bold fold scold/ bone drone shone/ long prong strong/ book cook look hook/ cool fool pool tool/ moon noon spoon

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Fop hop lop sop top/ cork fork york stork/ born corn horn scorn/ got hot pot rot spot/ broth cloth froth north/ love dove glove move

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Sour pour lour scour/ out pout gout pout/ low blow snow glow/ cub tub rub club club/ huff bluff snuff cuff/ hug lug rug mug

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Dull cull scull trull/ mum drum crum/ gun run sun pun/ bur cur furr spur/ cure sure pure lure/ curl furl hurl churl

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Urn turn burn churn/ bush push hush rush/ busk dusk husk musk/ dust must rust crust/ but cut nut hut slut

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: 32 words in squares, separated by small symbols or devices cut from brown, orange, and green Dutch paper. Border and verso covered in faded blue paper. Card shows signs of wear and soil.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: in of for the/ they when what/ that my with but/ which there their/ his her him he/ me she thy/ love shall where well/ will all our/ have from must most

did.unittitle: Set 11. George William Johnson his Book

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: Mother's name on verso of leaf 36: Iane Iohnson. Thirty six numbered leaves. Words in black on recto, lessons in now-faded red on verso. Bound in brown, orange, and green Dutch paper. Spine damaged, revealing cord ties. Hand-colored printed pictures pasted therein.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Title page: George William Iohnson his Book. Printed and Bound by his Mamma 1745.
Verso: First read all/ the black/ Lessons, and/ then read the/ red ones.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Bad had lad/ fad mad glad/ Bag lag nag/ wag rag tag/ All ball call/ fall tall wall/ Ham ram cram;
Verso: I/ hope my/ Dear now/ you have read/ the black les/sons, you will/ read these/ pretty red ones/ very well.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Man pan fan/ can nan/ Bang hang/ gang fang/ Ant pant rant/ Cap lap map/ Bar far star/ Gard card hard;
Verso: My Son/ pray attend/ The Advice/ of your/ friend/ And strive to mend.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Dark bark mark/ ... etc.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: Thirty-two numbered leaves. Colored pictures pasted therein. Bound in brown, orange, and green Dutch paper.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Concludes: "The End of This Book."

scopecontent.head: Scope Note
scopecontent.p: Set of six unnumbered lesson cards of 4 lines each. Verso of each pasted with playing card symbols cut from brown, orange, and green Dutch paper. 6 items.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: ALL Men seek pleasure,/ Tho by different way;/ But each Looses his Aim,/ When from Virtue he strays.

did.unittitle: [2] I wou'd not but do the thing

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: I Wou'd not but do the/ Thing that is Right,/ Tho I got, or I lost the/ Universe by it.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: IN Heaven are joys, and/ Pleasures ever new,/ And Blessings thicker/ Than the Morning Dew.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: WHoever Breaks the/ Holy Sabbath day,/ Unbless'd shall pass the/ Other six away.

did.unittitle: [5] Whoever makes his parent's heart to bleed

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: WHoever makes his/ Parent's Heart to bleed/ Shall have a Child, that/ will revenge the Deed.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: WHoever Swears or/ Lightly Speaks the Name/ Of God Supreme is/ Cursed for the same.

scopecontent.head: Scope Note
scopecontent.p: Set of 40 unnumbered lesson cards of religious and secular topics, fables, remedies, and verses, arranged by first lines. With cord hangers, borders in brown, orange, and green Dutch paper. Verso pasted with cut-out colored figures, occasionally related to the lines on the recto. 35 items.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: All Wisdom comes down/ From the Great God above/ And to Practice that Wisdom/ Is Friend-ship and Love/ Be not Peevish, or cross/ But be Merry and glad,/ For good Boys have no cause/ For to Cry, or look sad.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Ambrose Brooks, and Abel Bark-/ er, Groom, and Butler to Sir/ Stephen Marwood, one of them car-/ rying a Venison Pasty out of the/ Parlour, which was for Dinner at/ the first Course, & the other carrying/ a Dish of Tarts and Cheese-cakes/ for the Second Course.

did.unittitle: [3] As the Goat goes to browze

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: As the Goat goes to browze,/ Thus her Charge does begin;/ Be advis'd, my dear Kid,/ And let Nobody in./ The Wolf over-hearing/ For Admittance does try,/ But the kid answer'd, no;/ I'll not trust you, not I.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: A Bee Stung a Bear, and for/ the rash Action,/ The Bear from the Hive wou'd/ Demand Satisfaction:/ While he rifles the Hive, a/ Swarm of Bees flies out,/ And stings the poor Bear, till/ they stung both his Eyes out.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: The Blessed Virgin Mary,/ with Jesus Christ Sucking/ at her breast, & riding upon an/ Ass; as the custom was in those/ days. She is going into Egypt,/ as the angel directed Joseph/ in a dream, in order to avoid/ King Herod's cruel Massacre.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: The Circumcision of Jesus/ Christ, when he was but eight/ days old; according to the Law/ of Moses, that every Male Child/ shou'd be circumcised. which/ Law was first given by God him-/ self, to the Patriarch Abraham,/ when he was ninety nine years/ old

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: A Clown that was vext with/ abundance of Flies,/ To drive them away with/ a Firebrand tries:/ This while he with wonderful/ Courage essays,/ His thatch'd Habitation is/ set in a Blaze.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: A Cock upon a Dunghill bred,/ Finding a Jewel, only said,/ Some Jeweller, with High Esteem,/ Would doat upon this Taudry Gem;/ One Barley Corn I had rather see,/ For what are Diamonds to me.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: David Morris, one Farmer/ Nicholas Bagshaw's/ Shepherd, with two Sheep, in/ Orton Field in the County of/ Westmoreland, he is driving/ one of them along. with his/ Hat, to Burton market to sell it.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Doctor Berkley the good/ Bishop of Cloyne in Ireland;/ advising Mrs. Wilson who has/ got a Cancer in her Breast to drink/ Tarwater, and he is likewise send-/ ing Patrick Norway his Servant/ with a Pitcher of Tarwater, to a/ poor woman in Schoolhouse-lane/ that has got an Ague and Fever.

did.unittitle: [11] A dog that was an errant thief

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: A Dog that was an Errant Thief,/ Had Stole, it seems, a piece of Beef;/ And o'er a River swam, for fear/ Justice should fall upon his Rear:/ The Figure of this Beef did seem/ so lively painted in the Stream,/ That he for a fresh Booty hope'd/ And greedy at the Shadow chopt:/ So he let go the Prize he had,/ which vex'd him so, that he ran mad.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Enoch Martyr, Footman to/ the Bishop of Cloyne; filling/ six large jars, in order to make/ Tarwater, which is the best/ Medicine in the world for a Fever,/ Consumption, the Small pox,/ Kings Evil, & all sorts of disor-/ders, & to preserve health.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: The story of the master who killed his faithful dog which saved his child from a snake.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: A Farmer came home, and his Cradle he found,/ Turn'd quite topsy-turvey, the cloths on the ground/ He frown'd at his Dog by the Cradle that Stood;/ And Seeing his Mouth smeer'd over with Blood,/ He Stab'd him in Anger, without looking further;/ He took it for granted his dog had done Murther:/ But turning the Cradle, he found his Mistake,/ The Child was alive, but there lay a dead Snake,/ with the poor faithful Cur, to stay a Disaster,/ Had Slain in Defense of his hard-hearted Master.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: A Great many Gentlemen, and/ Ladys, at a table, at dinner, at/ a Marriage, at Cana of Galilee;/ when Jesus Christ, perform'd that/ great Miracle, of turning six/ large pots full of water, into the/ finest of wine, with only a word/ speaking.

did.unittitle: [15] A great many pretty little angels

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: A Great many pretty little/ Angels, riding upon the/ Clouds, to meet Master Jacky/ Dashwood, who is just dead, and/ because he was very good, and/ made it his constant Study to please/ God; is now going to Heaven, and/ the angels are all very glad to see him.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: A Hedgehog that was on his/ Journey benighted,/ A Snake very kindly to/ Shelter invited:/ The Hedgehog approv'd of/ the Lodging so well,/ The Snake could no more/ get him out of his cell.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Jesus Christ, when he was but/ six weeks old, brought to the Tem-/ ple at Jerusalem, & presented to/ the Lord; by the High Priest; who/ has him in his Arms, & the Virgin/ Mary kneels down, & offers a Sacri-/ fice, of two young Pidgeons, as the/ custom was in those days, according/ to the Law of the Jews.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: John Pope, a good old Shepherd repeat-/ ing the following verses to himself./ All covet Happiness/ But Oh! how few/ To Gain that Happiness/ The Right way pursue./ More pains men take/ to serve the Fiend of Hell/ Than they need take, in/ Realms of Bliss to dwell.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: The Lion Brave and Generous,/ Once in his Life had sav'd a Mouse,/ And little thought in time to see/ The Mouse as Generous as he;/ Till being hamper'd in a Net,/ Where 'twas in vain to roar and fret,/ He found what he expected least,/ His Safety from so small a Beast./ The Mouse did that which made him wonder/ And gnaw'd the stubborn Snare asunder.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Master Isaac Seabright, Son/ to Sir Charles Seabright, a/ dying of Convulsion-Fits when he/ was but three days old; his Nurse/ sits by him, and Doctor Thomas,/ Bishop of Lincoln, is going to/ Baptize him before he is quite/ dead.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Mr. Christopher, an old He/ Goat, with a huge long/ Beard, eating thistles, in Sir/ Francis Morgan's Park in Radnor-/ shire in Wales, and Martin Lum-/ ley a Plough Boy going to drive him/ away, or else to catch him with his/ hands.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: More instances of wicked/ King Herod's cruelty/ in killing the young children. O!/ What a sad vile creature he was,/ who wou'd not rather be a Beggar?/ a Chimney Sweeper? nay or a/ Tom-Turd-man than such a king.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: An old country Squire lov'd Dogs at (his heart),/ And he & his Kennel cou'd ne'er dwell apart;/ But one day his Son by a Villanous Hound/ was bit so severely, he died of the Wound:/ which put the old Spark in so grevious a passion/ past Condemnation;/ So Ringwood, & Jowler, & Rockwood & Tray,/ Tho' harmless, were hang'd as they (came in the way.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Oronoko, a Black Boy, Page to/ his Grace the Duke of Northum-/ berland, telling Oliver Brom-/ field the Duke's Gardiner; that he/ must bring in some Cucumbers/ green Pease, Kidney-Beans, Horse-/ Radish, Asparagus Artichokes &/ Colly-Flowers, ready for Dinner.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: An Oxford Scholar in/ his Study, sitting by a/ Table with Mathematical/ Instruments before him, and/ a Globe of the World standing/ on the ground by him.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Plato, Socrates, and Seneca, three/ of the Ancient Wise Philosophers/ talking together about the Immor-/ tality of the Soul, the Happiness of a/ future Life, & the shortness of this;/ As one Drop of water/ To the Boundless Sea;/ Is the longest Life, compar'd/ To Eternity.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Rowland, & Rosamund Percival/ an honest country man & his wife/ walking to Sturbridge Fair to sell/ Eggs, Apples & Turneps, & to buy/ a new Hat, Stockings, Shoes, Lea-/ ther Breeches, and a Knife and/ Fork for their little son Edward/ who is a very good Boy & cou'd write/ & Read before he was eight years old.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: A Schoolboy was once so dull in his way,/ He cou'd not be taught so much as great A/ His Schoolfellows jested upon his thick skull/ Nay, hold, says the Youngster, I am not so dull;/ But if I learn A, which I cou'd soon do,/ They'll put me to B, C, & all the Cross Row:/ Now that wou'd exceedingly trouble my (Gizard,/ For learning of A, to be run down to Izard.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: Refers to April 9, 1747.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Simon Lord Lovat; sitting in the/ Tower leaning upon a stone Pillar;/ and Edmund Newton his Servant/ bringing him a large glass of French/ Brandy. On thursday April the/ ninth, one Thousand, seven-Hun-/ dred, & forty seven his Head was/ Cut off, on Tower Hill for High/ Treason: he being then fourscore/ years of age.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: A Stork thro' Misfortune,/ Was trapann'd with a Crane;/ He pleaded his good Deeds,/ But pleaded in vain./ The Crane is a Villain,/ The Farmer replies,/ And he that's his Comrade/ Most certainly dies.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: There was a grey Cat,/ And She got up a tree,/ And when she was there, She/ Was Stung by a Bee/ Which made her cry Mew, and/ Down jumped She.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: There was a little Man,/ And he had a little Gun,/ He Shot at two Crows, and/ He killed but one./ The other Flew away,/ For he did not choose to stay,/ For fear he should Shoot him/ Before he had done.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: There was a little Mouse/ And She came to our house,/ And a great black Cat,/ That was very fat,/ Did kill this pretty Mouse,/ That came to our House.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Two tame Swans swimming/ in the River they are the/ Property of George Wrighte/ Esquire, Member of Parliament./ of Gothurst, or Gay-Hurst near/ Newport Pagnel in the County of Bucks.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: The boy who cried wolf.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: A Wanton young Shepherd,/ Tho' no danger near,/ Bawls out, Help! Neighbours, help/ The Wolf, Sirs, is here./ They come, but are laugh'd at:/ Soon he roars, out again,/ Now the Wolf's here indeed,/ But he roars out in vain.

did.unittitle: Set 15. All Wisdom cometh from the Lord

scopecontent.p: Set of lesson cards, Nos. 1-8, religious in nature. Borders and verso in brown, orange, and green Dutch paper with cord hangers. 8 items.

did.unittitle: 1. All wisdom cometh from the Lord

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: All Wisdom cometh from/ the Lord, to fear the/ Lord, that is Wisdom.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Whose feareth the Lord/ it shall go well with him;/ he shall find favour with/ God and men.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: They that fear the Lord/ will obey his word, and/ they that love him will/ keep his laws

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Love the Lord all they/ life, and think of him/ every hour for he sees/ all you do.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: All your ways are known/ to the Lord, and can-not/ be hid from his Eyes.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: The eyes of God are always/ upon you, and you can-not go/ out of his sight.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Make they prayer unto God/ and offend not the Most High/ in word or deed.

did.unittitle: 8. Love the God that made thee

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Love the God that made/ thee, with all thy strength,/ with all thy heart, and with/ all thy Soul.

scopecontent.head: Scope Note
scopecontent.p: Group of 6 unnumbered lesson cards of assorted sizes, each with brown, orange, and green Dutch paper border, cord hanger, and picture on verso except as noted. 6 items.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: As a hungry Eagle was/ Seeking for Prey,/ He spy'd a young Child in/ A Cradle that lay;/ the Mother was absent,/ And no creature by,/ So the Baby he seiz'd and/ Flew up to the Sky:/ The Child cry'd and scream'd/ But his Tears were in vain,/ For his Life was soon ended,/ And with it all pain.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: No hanger

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: As one drop of Water to the Great/ and Wide Sea: or as one Grain of/ Sand to the Multitude on the Sea Shore,/ so is the Longest Life, when compared/ with the days of Eternity. Then/ what would it profit a Man to gain the/ whole World, and Lose his own Soul?/ Would not that man be worse than a Fool,/ that would accept of the whole World/ or of any thing in it upon such very/ bad terms.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: 'Count that Day lost, whose/ 'Low descending Sun,/ 'Tells from thy Hand, no/ 'Worthy Action done.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: Title of card: The Old Man and Death. A Fable.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Quite spent with a Burthen of Sticks, an old Clown/ To rest himself, on a Bank sat him down:/ Then call'd upon Death, and beg'd he wou'd please/ To shorten his Life, that he might have some ease./ Straight all of a sudden, pale Death did appear,/ Which made my old Gaffar's Teeth chatter with Fear;/ I call'd you, says he, Mr. Death in a Maggot,/ But now you are here, help me up with my Faggot.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Roger Bowyer, with a Sheep/ that has its Legs tied to-/ gether, hanging over his arm;/ he is going to sell it, at Cole-/ brook Market, & as he walks a-/ long he hears the Cuckoo Sing,/ which makes him lift up his/ hand in great surprize, it being/ in the month of March.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: Words only, verso paper covered.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Sun moon stars fire air earth Sea/ light dark cold heat east west/ north south wind rain hail/ ice snow frost thaw dew mist/ cloud sky night day hour week/ month year foot tooth breast.

did.unittitle: Set 17. As John with his rake

scopecontent.head: Scope Note
scopecontent.p: Set of 44 unnumbered lesson cards on secular subjects with related colored picture in center of card. Verso, plain. 44 items.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: As Iohn with his/ Rake went out to make Hay,/ He met with his/ Sweet heart, and/ stopt by the way.

did.unittitle: [2] At a house by a gate

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: At a house by a Gate,/ Did live without state/ A little old woman/ and man,/ They did work for/ their bread, And were/ very well fed. and the/ old woman's name it/ was Nan.

did.unittitle: [3] At a house by a steeple

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: At a House by a/ Steeple, Did live many/ people, who all did/ love pudding, and pye./ And good bread, and/ good meat, which they/ each day did eat, and/ drank small Beer/ when they were a dry.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Carots and Turnips/ all fresh good and/ fine,/ There is none to be/ had that are better/ than mine.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: A Cat and two/ Mice Lived in a/ great Barn, the/ Cat killed the/ Mice, and she/ thought it no harm.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Close under a tree/ there stood a pretty house/ And in it did live a great/ Rat, and a Mouse/ The Mouse she fell/ sick, and long kept her/ bed; The Rat went in/ Mourning for her when she was dead.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: A Cow and a Bull one/ day for their good,/ Would try change of/ Air, and walk to the/ Wood:/ But when they came/ there, they found little/ ease, Their feet were/ so hurt, with the stumps/ of the trees.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Dear Madam your Tea/ is exceedingly Fine,/ I had rather drink/ Tea, than the finest of Wine.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: A Duck and a Drake/ jumpt into the water/ And all the young/ Ducks did paddle/ in after.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: The Eagle Flies/ high,/ But can't touch/ the Sky.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Eye ear arm face lips/ nose cheek teeth skin/ mouth hair tongue/ throat neck heart let/ hand feet thumb nail.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Fish Flesh Fowl fruit/ bread cheese oil Ale/ Wine Beer drink salt/ Sauce Eggs spice/ Butter pepper greens.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: A Fox caught a/ Goose, and eat her/ for dinner,/ A Man Shot the Fox/ while the Goose was/ within her.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: From most must/ take wick wild/ which George good/ thought strength lip.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Give some Bread/ to my Children I/ beg and I pray/ or they will be/ starved having/ had none to day.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Good Girl make/ haste and have/ done with your broom/ Of all things I hate/ such a dust in the Room.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Hark the Drum/ beats, and calls/ to the Field./ God give us Suc/ cess and make the/ French yield

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Have you got any/ Copper or Brass to/ mend:/ The Tinker to/ serve you does wait/ and attend.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: How wicked these/ men are to Quarrel/ and Fight:/ They surely forget/ that they are in God's sight.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: I am old, and poor and/ blind, pray give me/ a penny to buy me/ some Bread.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: I never did see such a/ strange Bird as this is,/ He is ugly enought to/ fright little Misses.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: In a fine summer's day/ to Lye down on the/ ground,/ Is bad for your/ Health; and has fatal been found.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: In Frost and Snow,/ when Winds do/ blow, Little Robins/ do whistle and Sing./ Of all Birds, they/ are best, with their pretty Red Breast/ And their Musick/ does make the Wood's/ ring.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Indeed little Madam/ you Ride very grand/ With a Crown on/ your Chair, and a Fan/ in your hand.

did.unittitle: [25] It is wicked to get drunk

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: It is wicked to get/ drunk, to swear, lye, or/ steal./ And those that do such/ things will Hell Torments feel.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: A Linnet, and a/ Thrush. Sitting in/ a Bush./ For three Months in/ the Spring, They/ most sweetly do Sing.

did.unittitle: [27] Maids will you buy any milk

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Maids will you/ buy any Milk, will/ you have some or/ no, Unless you/ come quickly, away/ I must go.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: May can say his let/ use new men man/ she when that they/ with your what them/ will well this have/ then than know yet

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: George Iohnson. Watermark.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Oh had I wings I would/ Fly like this Dove,/ To visit Miss Wrighte/ who so dearly I love.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Of all the fine Birds/ that fly in the Air,/ None can with the/ Peacock, for beauty/ compare.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Of in at to me my it/ is no all go so if up/ or by he we be us as/ do on and for the/ thy not our out you/ but her him was now

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Once on a time it did/ so come to pass,/ That a Buck, and a Doe/ and a little Jack Ass,/ Did all live in one/ Field, where they eat/ Hay, and Grass.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Rock on, rock on/ my pretty Boy/ And you shall be/ your Mothers joy.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: A Shepherd and a/ Shepherdess a keeping/ of their Sheep,/ They Guard them both/ by day and night and/ Fold them when they/ sleep.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: There was a Birds/ nest, and in it three eggs/ And when they were/ hatch'd each Bird had two legs.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: This Girl went out/ To walk about, till she/ had walk'd enough./ Then she set her/ Rump, upon a stump/ And took a pinch of/ snuff.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: This is Jack Woodhouse/ a riding to School/ To Play with the/ Boys and Learn/ Latin by Rule.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: This little Boy waits/ to have his Shoes/ mended,/ With the Cobbler/ he stays, until the work's ended.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: This man with his Dogs/ went out to Kill Game,/ His Gun it went off,/ and shot the Dogs/ lame.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Two Butter Flys/ painted with wings/ fine and gay,/ Did both come to Life/ one very fine day.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Two for a penny/ Oranges, all sound/ and sweet,/ Come try them/ and buy them of/ me in the street.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Upon a high hill there/ stood a Wind-Mill, and/ unless it is gone it/ stands there still. And/ who ever does please,/ when ever they will/ may bring Corn to/ Grind at this pretty Hill.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: When the Hawk/ comes in sight,/ The Birds are all/ in a fright.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: A Wind Mill stood/ near to the end of a/ Town, At which they/ Ground Corn both/ for white Bread and/ brown./ The Miller was not,/ a right just, honest man/ For he sometimes stole/ Flour, and made weight/ with good Bran.

did.unittitle: Set 18. A boy and a girl did eat sugar

scopecontent.head: Scope Note
scopecontent.p: Group of 9 unnumbered word and verse cards. Each with large plain picture in center, verse at top and bottom, words on sides, verso plain, string hangers, brown, orange and green Dutch paper trim. 9 items.

did.unittitle: [1] A boy and a girl did eat sugar

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: top: A Boy and a Girl, did/ eat Sugar and Plumbs/ Till they made their teeth
bottom: ake, and fall from their gums;/ And then they could eat,/ nothing but bread crums.
left: long/ went/ next/ play/ true/ like/ take
right: give/ move/ ball/ both/ came/ care/ come

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: Lettering on left and right sides is faint.

note.label: Transcription:

scopecontent.head: Scope Note

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: The same as no. 3 in set 22 and no. 3 in set 23.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: God made you, and/ all the world; he made/ the Sun, the Moon, and/ all the Stars.

scopecontent.head: Scope Note
scopecontent.p: Group of 6 cards with verses relating to dress and social activities, and hand-colored pictures with printed Nos. 11, 13, 14, 15, 18, and unnumbered. String hangers. Brown, orange, and green Dutch paper borders and verso.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: How smiling and pleasant these all look in the face/ To see this young Girl dance with such a Grace./ One plays on the Pipe, the Dog he lies by/ They all take my fancy, and much please my Eye.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: How pretty this Man looks, with Sword, Hat, and Cane/ One Lady seems Sick, or to be in some pain:/ The other walks off, and points with her Fan/ Saying help I will fetch you, as fast as I can.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: This Lady looks smart, and her dress is quite fine/ But I rather choose to wear such clothes as mine/ For petticoats short, and a Hoop that is less/ Tho' not quite so grand, is a more easy dress.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: Printed source: sold by John Bowles at the Black Horse in Cornhill

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Pray Madam come this way, one Gentleman crys,/ This Walk is more free both from Sun-shine, and Flys:/ No Sir says the Lady; it is this way I choose/ If that walk you like, pray your Liberty use.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Such short Gowns as these, are much used in France;/ And the Men, and the Women cut capers and dance./ The Ladys they Paint, and their backsides they show,/ The Men hop, and skip, and each one is a Beau/ Would you see men like monkeys; to France you must go.

did.unittitle: [19] This girl to get money does dance

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: This Girl to get money does dance on a Rope/ She will sure have good luck if her neck is not broke/ Quite hard is her fortune, her fate most unkind/ If no way for a living but this she can find.

did.unittitle: Set 22. There is but one God and he is good

scopecontent.head: Scope Note
scopecontent.p: Set of lesson cards, Nos. 1-57, of religious and moral sayings. Each with Arabic and Roman numerals. Ink borders, colored pictures on verso. A brief description of the pictures is provided.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: fish

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: There is but one God,/ and he is good./ Love God for he is good.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: two birds

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: A good Boy will be a/ good man/ Love to Read your Book.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: an elephant and a unicorn

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: God made you and all/ the world, he made the/ Sun, the Moon, and all/ the Stars.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a maiden and two birds

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Speak the Truth and/ tell no Lyes/ Use no ill words.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a young man and a dog

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Love good Boys, and play/ with none that swear, or lie,/ or steal.

did.unittitle: 6. If you are in the dark

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: three men and a woman

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: If you are in the dark/ God sees you, and if you/ are in the light he is/ with you.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a bird, a bull, and a lamb

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: God is in all pla-ces He/ Knows all that is done, and/ you can-not go out of his/ Sight.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a man, a woman, and an owl

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: God sees e-ve-ry thing you/ do, hears e-ve-ry word you/ speak, and knows e-ve-ry/ thing you think.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a pigeon and a man

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: God loves you better/ than your Fa-ther or your/ Mo-ther love you.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a bird, a bull, and a goat

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: God sends you e-ve-ry/ thing you Eat and Drink,/ and all the fine things/ you have.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a wild boar

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: God made the Day Light/ that you may Walk and/ Play, and he made the Night/ Dark, that you may Rest and/ Sleep.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a woman and a boy

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: God is al-ways with you tho'/ you can-not see him, and if you/ are good he will not let a-ny/ thing hurt you.

did.unittitle: 13. God made you for no other reason

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a tiger

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: God made you for no o-ther/ Rea-son but to make you/ hap-py, but you can-not be/ hap-py with-out be-ing good.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a fantastical creature and clovers

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: If you are good you will go to/ hea-ven when you Die, and be/ hap-py for e-ver and e-ver.

did.unittitle: 15. Heaven is a much finer place

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a monkey playing a drum

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Hea-ven is a much Fi-ner/ place than e-ver you saw/ in your Life.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a man and a maiden with a basket of apples

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: When you go to Hea-ven you/ will see God, you will ne-ver/ feel a-ny pain, and you will/ have e-ve-ry thing you wish/ for.

did.unittitle: 17. It is very easy to be good

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a monkey and a man

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: It is ve-ry ea-sy to be good/ and none but Fools will/ e-ver do a wick-ed thing.

did.unittitle: 18. To be good is to love God

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a king and a queen

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: To be good is to love God,/ and to strive to please him/ in thought word and deed.

did.unittitle: 19. To love God is to keep

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a woman and two cherubs

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: To Love God is to keep/ his Com-mand-ments and/ They are all ve-ry ea-sy.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a maiden with fire

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: God spake these words and/ said, I am the Lord thy God;/ Thou shalt have no o-ther/ Gods but me.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: cats

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Thou shalt not take the/ Name of the Lord thy God/ in vain.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: two fantastical creatures

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Re-mem-ber the Sab-bath/ Day to keep it Ho-ly: In/ it thou shalt do no man-ner/ of work.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a lion and a tiger

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Thou shalt not steal./ Thou shalt not tell a Lye.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a man and a monkey

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Ho-nour thy Fa-ther and they/ Mo-ther, that thy days may/ be long in the Land.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: two birds

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Al-ways do un-to o-thers, as/ you would have them do/ un-to you.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a pheasant and a swan

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Hurt no-body by word or/ Deed, and do all the good you/ can to all men.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: figure with hat

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Those that Love God, and keep/ his Com-mands will all go to/ Hea-ven, when they die, and/ be a vast deal more happy/ than they can be in this World.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a camel and a bear

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Those that Steal, tell Lies,/ or Swear, or get Drunk, will/ ne-ver go to Heaven.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: figure smoking a pipe

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: The De-vil is a Ly-ar:/ Ly-ing Lips are hate-ful/ un-to God.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: two figures on horses

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: He that tells one Lye shall/ not escape with-out some/ pun-ish-ment.

did.unittitle: 31. God is the God of truth

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: two fantastical creatures

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: God is the God of Truth, and/ none can please Him un-less/ they speak the Truth from/ their heart.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: four figures

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Pray of-ten to God, and let/ not one hour pass with-out/ think-ing that He knows/ all you say and do.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a man and woman strolling and a man and woman drinking tea

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Al-ways do good for e-vil,/ but ne-ver do e-vil for good;/ and then God, and all good/ men will Love you.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a boy and a girl

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: of all the plea-sures in Life/ the great-est is to do good.

did.unittitle: 35. It is better to be good

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a young man and a boy with his dog

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: It is better to be Good than/ to be Rich, or Fine, or hand-some.

did.unittitle: 36. You ought to be more afraid

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: three religious figures

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: You ought to be more a-fraid/ of Sin than of Death.

did.unittitle: 37. Heaven is such a fine place

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a man with a wheelbarrow and a hunter

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Hea-ven is such a Fine place,/ it is worth ta-king a great/ deal of pains to go there.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a baptismal scene

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Chil-dren o-bey your Parents/ in all things, for that is well/ pleas-ing un-to God.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: two military figures

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Ho-nour thy Fa-ther and they/ Mo-ther both in Word and/ Deed, that a Blessing may come/ up-on thee from the Most High.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: an orange tree, a young child, and a man and woman

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Who-so does Ho-nour his/ Fa-ther shall have joy of/ his own Chil-dren and be/ bless-ed of God with long/ life.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: two fish

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: My Son help thy Fa-ther/ when he is old, and grieve/ him not so long as he lives.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a goat and a plant

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Bless-ed most bless-ed and/ hap-py is the man that/ ne-ver did a wick-ed thing.

did.unittitle: 43. My son this life is short

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a dog and a maiden

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: My Son this Life is short,/ but the Life to come will/ last for e-ver and e-ver.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a horse

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: If you are good you will/ be hap-py, but if you will/ be wick-ed you must feel/ pain and tor-ment.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a king

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: A Fool will be wick-ed,/ but he that is Wise will/ be good.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: A woman with a small bird

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: To tell a Lye is a sad/ thing, for Ly-ing Lips/ are hate-ful un-to God.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a man and a bell

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Do no e-vil so shall no/ harm come un-to thee: for/ God will Bless thee in/ all thy ways.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a drum and a violin

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: No man can be hap-py in/ this World, or in the next,/ if he is not good.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a frog and a turtle

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: There shall no e-vil/ hap-pen un-to him that/ Loves and obeys the/ Lord his God.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a maiden and a young man

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: There are ma-ny things/ hate-ful un-to God, but/ few more so, than a man/ that gets Drunk.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a shepherd next to a burning tree

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: My Son if you va-lue/ health, drink but ve-ry/ lit-tle Wine, or Strong/ Drink of a-ny Sort.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: two men, a woman, and a branch

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Health is bet-ter than/ Rich-es, but to be good/ is bet-ter than both.

did.unittitle: 53. My son if you would have

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a boar and a fruit tree

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: my Son, if you wou'd have/ good health, drink no wine/ with-out water in it, till you/ are thir-ty years old.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a mouse and a rat

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: In the first place, take/ care to be good; and in/ the next, take care to be/ Rich.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a scrub brush and a book

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Ne-ver part with one/ half-penny with-out a/ ve-ry good rea-son.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: an hourglass

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: A Fool and his mo-ney/ are soon part-ed.

note.label: Description of item:
note.p: verso: a lantern

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: He that will not take/ care of two pence, will/ ne-ver be worth a groat.

did.unittitle: Set 23. There is but one God and he is great

scopecontent.head: Scope Note
scopecontent.p: Set of lesson cards, Nos. 1-37, of religious and moral sayings. Arabic numbering only. Hand-colored pictures below sayings. Each with brown, orange, and green Dutch paper borders and verso, string hangers.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: There is but one God,/ and He is Great, and/ High above all things/ that are in Heaven/ and Earth.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: God is Good and Wise,/ and Great above all/ men and all Angels.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: God made you and all/ the World, He made/ the Sun, the Moon,/ and all the Stars.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: God is every where and/ in all places, He knows/ every thing that is done/ and you cannot go out/ of His Sight.

did.unittitle: 5. If you are in the dark

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: If you are in the dark,/ God sees you, and if/ you are in the Light/ He is with you.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: God sees every thing/ you do, Hears every/ word you Speak, and/ knows every thing/ you Think.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: God loves you better/ than your Pappa and/ Mamma love you.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: God sends you every/ thing you Eat and/ Drink, and all the/ fine things you have.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: God made the Day/ Light, that you may/ Walk and Play, and/ He made the Night/ Dark, that you may/ Rest and Sleep.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: God is always with you/ tho' you cannot see him/ and if you are good and/ love him he will not let any thing hurt you.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: God made you for no/ other reason but to make/ you happy, but you can-/ not be happy without/ being good.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: If you are good you will/ go to Heaven when you/ die and be happy for/ ever and ever.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Heaven is a much/ finer place than ever/ you saw in your life.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: When you go to Heaven/ you will see God, you/ will never feel any/ pain, and you will have/ every thing you wish/ for.

did.unittitle: 15. It is very easy to be good

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: It is very easy to be good,/ and none but fools will/ ever do a wicked thing.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: To be good is to love/ God, and to strive to/ please him in all your/ thoughts words and/ actions.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: To love God is to keep/ his Commandments and/ they are all very easy.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: God spake these words/ and said I am the Lord/ thy God: Thou shalt/ have no other Gods/ but me.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Thou shalt Worship and/ Adore the Lord thy God/ and him only.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Thou shalt not take the/ Name of the Lord thy/ God in vain.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Remember the Sabbath/ Day to keep it Holy: In/ it thou shalt do no/ manner of Work.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Thou shalt not steal./ Thou shalt not tell a lye.

did.unittitle: 23. Honour thy father and thy mother

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Honour thy Father and/ thy Mother. That thy/ days may be long in the Land.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Always do unto others/ as you would have/ them do unto you.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Hurt nobody by word/ or deed, and do all the/ good you can to all men.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Those that Love God, and/ keep his Commandments/ will all go to Heaven when/ they die, and be a vast/ deal more happy than/ they can be in this world.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Those that steal, or tell Lies/ or do any Wicked thing/ will never go to Heaven.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: The Devil is a Lyar:/ Lying Lips are hateful/ unto God.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: He that tells one Lye,/ shall not escape without/ some punishment.

did.unittitle: 30. God is the God of truth

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: God is the God of Truth,/ and none can please Him/ unless they speak the/ Truth from their heart.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Pray often to God and let/ not one hour pass without/ thinking that He knows/ all you say and do.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Always do good for evil/ but never do evil for good/ and then God and all good/ men will love you.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Of all the pleasures in/ Life the greatest is to/ do good.

did.unittitle: 34. It is better to be good

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: It is better to be good than/ to be Rich, or Fine or/ Handsome.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: You ought to be more/ afraid of Sin, than of/ Death.

did.unittitle: 36. Heaven is such a fine place

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Heaven is such a Fine/ Place, it is worth taking/ Some pains to go there.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Children obey your/ Parents in all things for/ that is well pleasing/ unto God.

scopecontent.head: Scope Note
scopecontent.p: Unnumbered lesson cards of religious and secular topics, arranged by first lines. With cord hangers, borders in brown, orange and green Dutch paper. Verso pasted with cut-out uncolored figures.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Attend the Advice/ of the Old and the Wise./ Be not angry, nor fret,/ But forgive and forget./ Can you think it no Ill/ to pilfer and steal?/ Do the Thing you are bid,/ Nor be sullen when chid.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Envy none for their Wealth,/ or their Honour, or Health./ Fear, Worship, and Love/ The Great God above./ Grow quiet and easy/ when Fools try to tease you./ Honour Father and Mother,/ Love Sister and Brother.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: It is dangerous Folly/ To jest with Things holy./ Keep your Books without Blot,/ And your Cloaths without Spot./ Let your Hands do no wrong,/ Nor Back-bite with your tongue./ Make Haste to obey,/ Nor dispute nor delay.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Never stay within Hearing/ Of Cursing and Swearing./ Offer God all the Prime/ Of your Strength and your time./ Provoke not the Poor,/ Tho' he lies at your Door./ Quash all evil Thoughts,/ And mourn for your Faults.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: Remember the Liar/ Has his part in Hell-Fire./ Shun the Wicked and Rude,/ But converse with the Good./ Transgress no good Rule,/ At Home, or at School./ Vie still with the Best,/ And excell all the rest.

note.label: Transcription:
note.p: When you are at Play,/ Take care what you say./ Excuse, but with Truth,/ The Follies of youth./ Yield a little for Peace,/ And let Quarrelling cease./ Zeal and charity join'd,/ Make you pious and kind.
